Plus super friendly staff, atmosphere great for hanging out solo or en masse, and a variety of different beverages. I'm grateful that I live down the street, because I get to visit regularly.
author: Tom V.

description:
High ceilings and lots of windows. Big mugs of coffee. Refuge from the rain.

And the PIES!

A range of savory sorts for starters. A plethora of sweet options for dessert. The former on this visit comprised of Chicken Pot Pie which consisted of just the right ratio of chunky chicken, swimming in a thick gravy and gratuitous veggies (e.g. peas), and surrounded by a flaky-yet-crusty-enough encasement that made me - the usually nonfat girl - want to get one on my next visit (and my friend loved it). 

The latter: a vegan blackberry-apple treat that was sweet but light. A smidge small given how thin it was. 

But that's totally fine: there were so many indulgent options remaining for future visits (all in various grades of crust, savory and sweet) that I will definitely be back.
author: Diane B.

description: This place is amazing! Definitely one of my favorite spots for brunch/lunch in the city. The berry pie is my favorite.
author: Dawn H.

description: These guys really know what they are doing, go and taste their pear pie which is my favorite and have a cup of black rose tea from zhena's gypsy . Delicious!
author: Beril Y.

description:
Every pie i have had here is to die for. They have this peach galette thing...ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh

Even better, they are open relatively late (10 PM), their coffee is yum, and their ingredients are locally sourced. (Their employees are cute, heyy)

The Grrrr Factor--parking in the Mission is a beeetch. Also, I feel like everyone stares at me when I pop a chromium supplement by the water jug. What, a girl's gotta control her blood sugar! Especially when she eats pie!!
author: Tara P.

description:
Good savory treats, awesome sweet, seasonal pies.

I live dangerously close to Mission Pie. It's hard to walk past their doors when I have a $20 bill in my pocket and I know what kind of sweet fruity heaven for which I could exchange that bill.

I like a pie that doesn't have a thick, hard crust, especially along the edge. I like a pie that uses fresh ingredients. I like a pie that makes people I share it with like me a little bit more. Friends, Mission Pie is that pie.

While I definitely appreciate the fact that Mission Pie does so much for the community, I don't take that in to account in my review of this place as a business. I feel that I'd be taking something away from the fact that they make a good pie at a decent price in a clean, friendly shop. Yum.
author: Rob I.

description: I love banana cream pie.  This place has the best banana cream pie I've ever had.  End of review.
author: Jean A.

description:
Morning time? Goat coffee and a scone. What a tasty cup and scone. Flaky, buttery, a touch of sweetness. Great crumb on that guy. Love it. Great coffee as well. 

Anytime? Banana cream pie. Not super sweet, taste the fresh bananas, great texture with the custard. The fruit pies are also tops...but the banana cream is craveable.

Not cheap - a good thing as it keeps me out of here on a daily basis.
author: Allegra F.

description: Great pie. I ordered the Banana Cream, and it was pretty close to perfection. Great banana taste. The coffee was also excellent, and the people behind the counter were friendly. I really enjoyed my coffee and pie experience...I tried to savor each bite, but it was so good I finished it within minutes. I was extremely tempted to order another piece.
author: Jordan C.

description: banana cream pie!!! $20. Great for parties
author: E T.

description: Best banana cream pie I've ever had!
author: Jamila A.

description:
After reading all the amazing reviews, I came in the morning after a run. I was too embarrassed to get a piece of pie for breakfast, so I ended up getting their ham and cauliflower quiche. Despite the fact that I don't really like ham (I only ordered it because the other quiche had too much cheese for me), it was decent, if small for the price ($4.50 I think). The crust was really good and made me wish I'd just gotten a piece of pie instead.

If I lived here, I'd definitely go back to try the fruit pies, but for now, I think the quiche was just three-star-worthy. Nothing worth a special trip, but it's a cute breakfast spot with lots of seating and reading material.
author: Emily A.

description:
My favorite pie in the whole wide world is banana cream pie so when I came here I was hoping to try some but they hadn't made it yet so instead I bought a box of their banana chocolate muffins, macaroons, and maple walnut scones.  I think this place is a bit pricey for what you get, but the flavors in all of the pastries I got were amazing.

My favorite was the banana chocolate muffin.  I loved how you could distinctly taste every flavor and it was so moist. I definitely have to come back here and try their banana cream pie soon!
author: Rachel L.

description:
I realize I will be disagreeing with most reviews here, but I have my reasons.

Several months ago I had some pie at a friend's party, we got into a whole big conversation about how much I love pie, how I have a 700 page book called "pie" with every conceivable recipe and how I had to cease and desist my attempt to make every recipe in the book, cover to cover, part way through after I'd gained quite a bit of weight from the project -- true story. Many ha-ha's and my friend starts telling me about Mission Pie.

So, finally I'm in the city, it's peach season (I LOVE peach pie) and all the stars are aligned, I go to Mission Pie for the first and last time. 

I walk in -- they're blasting rap music and the guy behind the counter can't stop rapping along (pardon me for coming in during your favorite song, sir) to speak to me. Yes, he does get me the peach pie and put it in a box and take my money (EIGHTEEN DOLLARS!!), but not a word from him to me. 

So I leave. Not a pleasant experience ambiance-wise, but I assure myself the pie will be worth it, the pie will be worth it. I think "oh my Jeebus, did I really just spend nearly $20 on a PIE??" but I tell myself it's organic and the pie will be worth it, the pie will be worth it. 

I think you know how this turns out.

The pie was NOT worth it. The crust is tasteless and burned -- oh, ok, burned is a taste, I suppose. No texture to speak of. A crust should be flaky and sweet and crunchy and a bit salty -- I KNOW pie, I KNOW pie crust. I make it a thousand times better than Mission Pie's. And the peaches? Well, those that are in there (it's not got many, so I'm not quite sure what that EIGHTEEN DOLLARS goes to) are NOT good. They're not sweet and they're not even peeled. OK, with most fruits I like when they're not peeled, keeps more nutrients in, yada yada. But peaches? You ALWAYS peel peaches because they're FUZZY. It's not pleasant having so much friction on the tongue. 

Argh, I'm mad at Mission Pie. I want my money back.
author: Sara C.

description: The coconut cream pie was FANTASTIC!  It was so good!  The whole place reminded me of my Grandma's house (Ok, there were no hipsters at my grandma's house.) I love it!
author: J F.

description: This place was really good.  After eating a heavy Chinese dinner, I didn't think I had room... No, I know I didn't have room for dessert.  But they're Banana pie felt like taking a bite of delicious air.  4 stars for the awesome food. -1 star for the mediocre service.  Overall very good, and I'd go back the next time we visit San Fran.
author: Mark T.

description:
Ode to Mission Pie:

Apple, peach, and pumpkin pie
Flavors make the tastebuds fly
It's the best dessert in all the city,
though sometimes service is kinda shitty...

But your flaky crust
hath gained my trust
And fresh whipped cream
completes the dream.

O how sweet or so savory,
everything here is super flavor-y
I like your vibe and free wi-fi
Thank you, spank you, Mission Pie.
author: Mari C.

description:
Love how they incorporate youth advocacy and sustainable local farming into their business....Bottom line they make really good pie. 

The Banana Cream PIe was delicious and the Pear-Raspberry was full of fruit with a great granola-like topping. 

Friendly service and great coffee to go with your slice of pie.
author: Elisabeth K.

description:
I've been here a few times now, so I feel like I can confidently give this place the 5-star rating it deserves.  Each of the slices of pie I've tried have been phenomenal.  The crust is buttery & flaky & tender, & everything tastes like it was pulled out of the oven no more than an hour beforehand.  My fave's the walnut pie, & I swear to you I hated walnuts until I tried this pie (it's particularly cool that they choose to make walnut pie instead of pecan pie because walnuts are local).  There's a bacon, tomato, & blue cheese galette there that's also amazing...I suppose you can't really go wrong with bacon, but it was delish either way.

Service each time was incredibly friendly, helpful, & patient (because seriously, it's difficult to decide with so many choices!).  They also have a fantastic youth advocacy & sustainability initiative that I can totally get behind.  

Quality pie + sustainability + empowering at risk youth = a place I'll be supporting on a regular basis.
author: Christy S.

description: I've ony tried the walnut pie and the rice salad with kale... Can't wait to try the rest! Parking can be a bummer so take bart. Decent prices...really really good pie! Go for it!
author: Krystal T.

description: Great pie! I haven't eaten here yet but I picked up a whole apple pie for a Friendsgiving dinner recently and everyone loved it. I'm not a big fan of apple pie but it was pretty yum. The service during my pick up was kind of meh. There could be more stars to come but I will reserve them for an update after I've actually eaten here and have tried other items. Can't wait to taste the savory pies!
author: Queenie C.

description:
I'm a New Yorker, but head out to San Francisco a fair bit for my ultramarathons. Mission Pie is around the block from a friend's house, and I've visited it a few times on my visits. I adore it, and wish it existed in NYC.

Their pies are amazing. Their vegan potpie is DELICIOUS. Their teas are great. Everything I've had is wonderful.

But mostly, I love the vibe. You can go there for hours, write, read, write letters, chat with a friend. I do that, and end up spending lots of money and eating tons of great things. Wonderful place.
author: cherie y.

description: Late night pie - pretty much a good thing in and of itself. However, the pies themselves here aren't really anything to write home about. I have been several times and, while the pie is perfectly enjoyable, the price per slice is reasonable, the service is friendly and the place is clean and inviting, I wouldn't wait in line for a slice. I've had their pear and raspberry pie and their Dutch apple, and, maybe it is because I am from 'pie country' (the Midwest) and have been spoiled by amazing pies, but I remain somewhat unimpressed. The crust is somehow lacking and the fillings need some pizazz. That being said, I will probably still go back when I am out in the Mission at night and craving something sweet, because, basically, why not?
author: Kathryn P.

description:
A few years ago when this place first opened, I had read an article in the SF Chronicle talking about how Mission Pie was run by Mission High School students, so I went and bought a tiny pie to support them. Their shop was pretty small, and everyone working at the front of the store looked really young. Now, the shop has expanded and is bigger than ever! I'm so happy for them!!

We came here yesterday so my lovely could get coffee, but I knew we couldn't leave without at least one slice of pie, even if it was the late morning. We got a slice of the pear-blueberry pie to go. It was delicious - really flaky pie crust, not-too-sweet fruit filling, and a crunchy and buttery oat/granola-type crumb topping, which I really loved. The prices are not cheap - $3.50 for a slice of pie, but almost all the ingredients that Mission Pie uses are either local or sustainable, so you are really supporting local businesses by coming here. 

The coffee is pretty strong here, and one of the ones that I tasted had nice fruity notes to it. The service is also very friendly. I'd love to come back here to try the other pies, especially this chicken pot pie that I saw this guy eating at the table across from us. I wonder if he noticed that we were sort of drooling while we gawked at his pie...
author: Yvonne W.

description:
wow, best darn pie i've had in the city (minus my friend's pie that she baked for me for my b-day)!

whole pies are available for $18-20. i've tasted both the plum frangipane and the vegan fresh peach with blueberry and both are FANTASTIC!!!

i will be back to sample more pies from Mission Pie. yummy!
author: Helen Y.

description:
I've been here twice now- once for a slice of banana cream pie as a treat and then another to pick up a pie as dessert for a get-together.  The banana cream pie didn't disappoint, and neither did the mixed berry pie I got for dessert.  Both pies had a great, flaky crust that was buttery without being overly full of fat and the fillings are really tasty- I especially enjoyed the large chunks of strawberry and raspberry in the mixed berry pie.  The crumble topping helped a bit as well.  The banana cream pie was also good- the pudding filling wasn't too sweet and it had a nice banana flavor.  Given the summer season, its good to take advantage of the bounty being offered by Mission Pie right now- I wouldn't mind going back for a slice of the other pies being offered.

So, why the 4 stars even though I clearly enjoyed my pies?  Unfortunately, the price is a little restrictive- $18 for a whole pie is a bit much to pay on a regular basis.  Alas, this shall mean that I'll have to wait for special occasions to warrant getting more pie from here.
author: Angela H.

description:
Charming.  Enjoyable.  Green.

Had it not been for the anticipation and over-hype, Mission Pie could have been a success.  

The ambiance is warm and jovial - people having educated discussion at the large round table, father and daughter sharing a moment at adjacent table, wood floors reminiscent of a simpler time, sun shining through the large windows.  You certainly can feel the happy, carefree waves at MP.

The pie however, while good, was not mind blowing.  The crust was soggy and paper thin, causing half of it to fall off before it hit my plate!  Cry!   The strawberry rhubarb was delicious!  ...but a whole of three bites.  Double cry. Based on my trusted yelp friends Genevieve and Juila though, I'm definitely going to have to give MP a round two.

I'd certainly go back for the ambiance alone or even to enjoy an earth friendly cuppa joe as well!

$3-6 for a slice - sizes vary!!
author: Jane L.

description: Ok. I will be the first asshole to say that the pies at Mission pie are not very good.
author: Bobby T.

description: Really awesome pies and great meeting and hang out space.  I ordered the peach & blueberry pie and it's so delicious! Cash or check only which can be a bummer when you're like me and just spent your last $12 on tacos :-)
author: Anna W.

description:
Their banana cream pie is to die for!!  (5 stars!)

Not sure about the service. How many times do I have to repeat my order before you can get it right? 2 slices of banana cream pie... 2. Banana cream. Repeat: 4 times. (3 stars)
author: Tina Y.

description:
I was bored and wandering around in the Mission District and came upon Mission Pie. Lucky me! I got a half bowl of the farro salad. It was tasty and super fresh with 2 different types of fresh tomato bites and cucumber and mint. The serving size was perfect and only $2.50

The mixed berry pie was melt in my mouth delicious! Fresh chunks of strawberries and blackberries with a sweet flaky crumble on top. 

$6 for a piece of pie and half bowl salad...definitely worth it!
author: Kamalpreet K.

description:
From the sweet, quirky ambiance to the wall with Chicken Club and Meat Share flyers to the beautiful display of all-organic pies, this place is welcoming and warm. 

I asked the manager on the phone before coming into town on vacation, and instead of the usual and dismissive  "Oh, yes, everything's organic," Sharon went into detail about how I could ask whomever is on duty and they can point me in the direction of what's organic in the case, which is basically EVERYTHING. Organic chicken pot pie (delish), organic vegan pot pie (which was incredibly delicious, almost better than the chicken pot pie), organic strawberry-rhubarb galette (out of this world), and the piece de resistance, the organic banana cream pie. The banana cream pie must be eaten to be believed. It is luscious, not too sweet, creamy and the pudding is flecked with vanilla seeds. The crust is flaky with a lovely caramelized flavor. We bought a whole pie to be enjoyed over the several days we're in town. 

Mission Pie is worker-owned, as well, which is a bonus. No exploited workers here! 
For the integrity of the ingredients, the luscious taste and the joyful feeling it leaves me with, Mission Pie earns 5+ stars!
author: Sabrina v.

description:
My friend and I came here for the first time to get some desert after hitting up El Farolito and it was packed! I can definitely understand why - This is a great local establishment with AWESOME pies. The workers were extremely friendly, and catered to all of our needs. WILL be coming back try all of their flavors. 

Keep it up Mission Pie!
author: Ryan L.

description:
*Banana Cream Pie Review*

My friend and I stopped by Mission Pie after a delicious meal at Beretta.  I got the banana cream pie (which I hear is supposed to be amazing) and my friend got the apricot-peach pie.  Her pie was really delish - not too sweet, and the crust was not too heavy.  My pie was kind of disappointing.  The flavors were good, but the banana cream was gelatinous instead of creamy...and there wasn't much fresh banana in my slice.  :(  I still prefer Nation's banana cream pie - cheap and delicious!
author: Fontane L.

description:
Chill & affordable, with a good banana cream pie.

$1.50 for a free-refills coffee mug.
author: Catherine H.

description:
TO DIE pies.
TO DIE space
TO DIE decor
TO DIE tables
TO DIE choices
TO DIE......incentives and purpose in the mish. xo
author: Marc K.

description: Solid sweet and savory pies. A little expensive and can't take longer than you would expect but the pies taste really good. Had the zuccini quiche and the rasperry pie and both were delicious.
author: Ojus P.

description:
First Papalote, now Mission Pies.  I'm beginning to see a pattern among Yelp reviews for Mission area businesses.  

The lemon shaker pie should be called lemon peel pie.  If you can handle the bitterness of lemon peels, you might like it.  For me, shit was disgusting.

Elitist, condescending hipsters may scoff at me for saying this, but this place isn't better than Nation's.  My taste buds don't give a shit about sustainability, and I don't believe in paying for an inferior product for the sake of supporting local businesses. 

You will love this place if you:

-are a tree-hugging, yuppy/hipster
-dress like al borland
-would like a place to sit around and talk shit about commercialized pop music and multi-billion dollar conglomerates.  
-paid 30 bucks for your american apparel white tee.
author: Per C.

description:
I had always wanted to try this place. I'm more of a pie person than a cake person (although who can resist either?). All the pies look good as well as their other baked goods and treats.

I had a slice of their peach raspberry pie ($3.5). Since the place was jam packed I ordered it to go. Be aware that they don't have any forks, knives, or spoons for to-go orders. I guess it's that whole green movement? They could at least have biodegradable utensils.

The pie is pretty good although not my ideal slice of fruit pie. It was too moist and soggy. The peaches were the canned kind. Plus the super thin crust doesn't help out at all. However the flavor and mouthfeel is satisfying. I felt a little cheated with the portions. I'm not fat, I just wanna get my money's worth.

Why is this place always full of caucasians?

CASH only.
author: Michael H.

description: I'm still not sure about the hype. I've gone twice and purchased sweet pies and didn't think they were that fabulous. I'll try one more time and get a savory pie, and update my review then.
author: T S.

description:
Oh, Mission Pie. You kept me from massacring and Columbine-ing pedestrian passerby after a douchebag kicked my baby's derailleur in, leading me to spend 3 hours at the Bike Kitchen attempting to fix the f*er. 

Your crumbly crusted mixed berry goodness is a staple in keeping the frustration down as I scrape the grease out from under my nails. 

Oh, and your wooden tables, none yet rickety, are awesome for those four-hour conversations about everything under the sun.
author: Amy S.

description: I AM IN HEAVEN! I had a strong craving for something sweet and decided to make a pit stop to Mission Pies. I ordered the banana creme pie and the peach/blueberry pie. I wanted the apple pie but apples were not in season. I never had banana creme pie and it was amazing! It was very light and the filling was a custard consistency. The peach/blueberry pie had a crumb topping, which had a nice sweet texture. The only con is the price.
author: Rosanna T.

description: Can't believe I've missed out on this place before. I wish they offered more variety, but I'm good for now. I got the banana cream pie and lamb curry pot pie. My husband got the apple/cheddar galette and the apple/blackberry pie. OMG...it was so delicious!!! I had my reservations about the galette, but I tasted it from my hubby and omg, it was delish! The banana cream pie was UH-MAZE-ING, and wow, even the lamb curry pot pie....I am definitely stopping by here again and very soon. :D
author: Maya B.

description:
I really like Mission Pie.  I like them because their roots are down south of Pescadero near Ano Nuevo and I know they have a great farm down there, and I like them because they are unpretentious and kind in a part of town that can either be pretentious or unkind alternatingly.  

It's a little haven, a kind, family home feeling place.
author: david c.

description:
Great pies yum! If your looking to eat great customer service don't come here, if looking for great product this is defenetly the place. Make sure you read the great story behind this business. 

The banana cream pie is a wonderland.

People inform yourself about what you put in your mouth!!!
author: Saulo A.

description: I love Mission Pie. What a great business model and what a great place to sit and chat. Its one of the few places where people aren't constantly on laptops and feels like real community.
author: Jay S.

description:
I have fallen in love with mission pie. All it took was a community celebration for their re-opening (check out the mural in the back and the sexy reclaimed sidewalk), and a few old people enjoying pie together as if it were their first date. Hell, maybe it was.

As far as I'm concerned, life would be better if we all slowed down and ate more homemade pie.
author: Jessa L.

description:
First, the huge communal European dining tables already give it a leg up from any other cafe around - cafe la bohem being another feel like this. 

Buckling to yelp pressure, I tried the banana cream. It's pretty damn good. I wish I had gone with my gut and went with Walnut... But I guess it gives me another reason to come back. 

Great coffee for cheap w/complimentary refill. Gets amazing sunlight in the afternoon. Perfect place to read and write during a lazy sunday.
author: Peter K.

description:
Starving, we left SF Street Food Festival and came to the first "cute" venue we saw. (Honestly, I made my friend come in here b/c I loved all the windows, and the adorable country-esque ambiance inside. I kind of had no idea what type of food they even served at the time, but I knew I wanted some.)

Once inside, I knew we may not have made the healthiest of decisions, but we made a good decision. Mixed Berry Pie to the rescue! It was tasty & good, but not as dense as the really good stuff that I love, though it was probably healthier, and made with more natural ingredients. Still, it also seemed more crumbly. Tasty, but not the best I've ever had.

One other plus: I LOVED the yellow/silver wallpaper behind the cash wrap, and the silver/gray crown-molding archway. Kudos to the interior designer, bravo! (It reminded me of a David Bromstad design - my favorite - from HGTV's Color Splash and/or Design Star.) :)
author: Sally M.

description:
I kept hearing Mission Pie had the best pie in SF.  Based on my small sampling, it was good but not necessarily the best.

The banana cream pie was average, suffered from a dearth of bananas and an excess of cream.  The flavor was good, maybe too sweet for my tastes, but then again--what are you doing in the pie game if sweetness ain't your thing?

The walnut pie was phenomenal however.  Tons of toasted walnuts held together with some gooey masonry work on a nice, flaky crust.  This is what pie is all about.  

Its too bad that I only managed to try two of their many pies during my time in SF.  If I could throw out the banana cream as an outlier, Mission Pie might earn the bump to five stars.
author: Christopher R.

description: Decent pie. Pretty uncomfortable seating, probably a nice place to pick up a last minute pie to-go, but if you're looking for something a little more comfortable you might want to look elsewhere.
author: John M.

description:
I can really appreciate and admire the high school students trying to learn a trade. That alone should be five stars. 

A friend bought me a slice ... THANK YOU! ... but after getting it home after a night of pizza and wine, the Lemon Pie just didn't do it for me. Maybe some kind of cream based with preserved lemon would have been better than this concoction of sliced lemons. The crust was dry and not flaky at all. 

Sorry kids, you should be commended on your efforts, but it just didn't do it for me. Check the menu for the daily offerings which seem to rotate monthly.
author: Michael M.

description:
First of all, I really don't like pies.  I don't know why, I never have, I'm a freak.  I also don't like cheesecake.  That being said, there are always a few exceptions.

I first went to Mission Pie a couple of years ago with a couple friends, when it was still very small and sort of under construction.  I had a walnut pie slice then, because I thought I'd experiment with something that sounded like it could be ok.  It was great!  I didn't go back for a long time though.


A few weeks ago one of those same friends and I thought we should try to find that small little place again.  To our surprise it was much larger and the entrance was on the front of the building instead of the side.  The coffee was good, the walnut pie was still great, and they have this gorgeous long wooden table that I really really REALLY love.  So now I can't help but want to go back, often, despite not even liking pie!  This place is great.
author: Meghan E.

description:
Believe yelpers when they say the banana cream pie is good. Try it...even if you don't like banana cream pie, or bananas. It has none of that artificial banana flavor going on. 

In addition to that gem, my friends and I had 4 other slices: 
Chicken pot pie
West African vegan peanut pie ( not my favorite, tasted like peanut sauce)
Potato Gratin
Pear & Margiapan
author: Alex N.

description:
All right . . . so I'm totally down with the purpose behind this place.  Sustainability . . . youth advocacy . . . sounds good to me.  Which is why I'm bumping them up to 4 rather than 3 stars.  Because the pie . . well, the pie is sort of average.  It's good, don't get me wrong.  But it's not great.  They do make their own whipped cream on the spot though.  It would be better warmed up and a la mode . . . maybe I'm being too picky about my pie.  But I take my pie seriously.

The other reason they get 4 stars is the service!  I found the "at risk youth" employees very pleasant and friendly.
author: Jenny R.

description:
I hate myself for loving pie so much that I'll put up with an eight word interaction between myself and an apathetic salesperson:

"Banana cream pie for Claire please"
"Twenty-two dollars"

...Thanks. I mean, the pies ARE good, but the service is a bit of a debbie downer. Two stars which I upped to three on the basis of their socially responsible practices.
author: Claire C.

description: I have been here a couple times, never been impressed. The pies are okay but not anything that can't be made at home for far cheaper. I got the peach raspberry pie last time and it was a bit bland; not sure how they managed that.
author: Pierre B.

description: The last time I came here was in August and it was my second visit. My partner and I came here at the end of a long walk on a hot day for our Thursday Tea date. The MP is one large airy room, yet on that day, hot with the afternoon sun beaming in; they only had one window open for ventilation. I found the Pies to be ok, but they lack consistent goodness. The place filled up quickly and was very noisy. There are a variety of tables, one big one that study groups tend to use, and a few different sized ones, and a small counter in the front window. That day they had two extra vendors stationed in the room, it made walking through the room difficult and more crowded, and also difficult to get to the counter and to the condiment station. Seems like poor planning/organization. They do have big tea pots, if you can get the staff to give you one. Good teas.
author: Herschell L.

description: Oh man, I just love everything about mission pie save for one thing. Food awesome, ambiance great, values spectacular. The ONE thing I really hate is that they don't take credit cards. Why is this even allowed anymore? Can they explain to me why they don't accept them? I own a cafe too, and I just don't see why they wouldn't accept plastic. I mean, is it a values thing? Because there are ways to deal with that. Is it because it's too expensive? Because, PLEASE. There are customers in there ALL THE TIME, so I don't believe that for a second. Why oh why? It's super lame and they need to get with the times. Please.
author: Minx A.

description:
Would it be wrong to eat an entire banana cream pie in one sitting...without sharing??? That's how I felt when I wolfed down a single slice during my first visit.  Yes...it was THAT good. 

Service behind the counter was a little slow because the guy was nice, chatty, but  a bit too mellow.  But, after tasting the pie...all was forgiven. 

Good airey space with two large communal tables and maybe 3 or 5 tables that can sit 1 or 2.  So, I can see this place getting crowded during peak hours, but at least you won't feel suffocated.

Over all, I plan to come back over and over again because I really like their crust. It was just the right texture. So, when the crust is good...I am open to almost any filling.
author: Aimey T.

description:
OMFG. I never knew pies could be this magical. I have always been a big dessert person but I never developed a love for pie... until today. Usually when I think of pie, I think of that canned fruit taste. Cherry pie? gross. Peach? eh. But if I had to pick a favorite, it would be banana cream. Still I could never tell if it's fresh, even if it was. And the crust could be too hard or not thick enough to go with its content. There'd be too much fruit or too much whipped cream. The list of things that could go wrong with any pie is endless and exhausting. This is why I was never a pie person. I could never find the right one!

I probably never would have gone into Mission Pie on my own but I was seduced in with a free slice coupon from the Green Zebra book. I ordered up a slice of the banana cream and my bf got a slice of the walnut pie. Now how do I even put this into words? I took one lick of the whipped cream and just knew this was going to be AMAZING. 

There was none of that canned whipped cream taste or consistency (even though I love canned whipped cream haha). Their whipped cream was silky, sweet, had the PERFECT thickness and it just gave you a feeling like someone had whipped it by hand, just for you. This cream was perfectly balanced with the banana portion. I got flavors of cool vanilla, smooth banana pudding, and fresh banana slices carefully placed into the most amazing crust. OMG the crust... it was flaky yet had a buttery firmness but still lightly crisp because it was so fresh. After every bite I had to stop and blurt out, "THIS IS SO GOOD!" 

Midway into my banana cream bliss I stopped to taste the walnut pie. I knew it was also delicious but my brain could not comprehend two amazing pies. I quickly went back to my own slice. Eventually and regretfully I finished but I savored every last lick of my fork.

I never knew pie could taste so satisfying for my taste buds and so fulfilling for my soul. Pie? Yes, please! Now that I've found THE ONE.
author: Julia T.

description: This place is the real deal. Had the lemon pie...had real lemon in it. Rind and all. Light sweetness but this pie is about the lemon...not artificial sweetners. I think this place rocks for a real pie experience.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
i have a mad passion for all things pie. sweet pies, savory pies, single-crust, double-crust, hand pies, slab pies; there's something about encasing your food in buttery, flaky goodness that just appeals to me. and like Ed U., i enjoy the countless crusts that appear in the pie-themed movie "waitress," as well as those in the tv show "pushing daisies". though i won't ever have a chance to visit lulu's pies or the pie hole, his review of mission pie convinced me that there was still hope for a hip pie shop within my reach. 

the unassuming cafe is bright and airy, with comfortable, worn-in tables begging for cheery conversations over thick slices of pie and cups brimming with coffee. the pies of the day, both savory and sweet, are chalked onto a steel beam near the glass counter, with slices running about $3.50 and whole pies $19-20. the menu is seasonal and everything they serve (down to the bottled apple juice!) is local; origins can be found on a poster-size map. 

i tried the spaghetti squash and niman ranch pork meatball galette for $5.50. the meatball was delicious, and i have never really liked spaghetti squash, but i found it paired perfectly with the meatball. next up, my favorite pie, banana cream pie. i loved that the smooth, rich filling has distinguishable slices of banana, and savored every bite. 

mission pie only accepts cash or local check, and be aware that you will want seconds! i had to make a mad dash to the ATM across the street for more cash, so i could take home a ham and corn chowder pot pie for dinner. that it's inconveniently placed in the mission actually worked out well for me; after two slices of banana cream pie, i needed the long walk back to my bus stop! this place might just become my new sunday afternoon hangout.
author: Kris G.

description:
Even though I think its really awesome what Mission Pie is doing, it still doesn't make up for the flavorless pumpkin pie.  If I didn't already know what I was eating was pumpkin pie I wouldn't have guessed.  I didn't taste any pumpkin and it lacked sweetness. 
I wanted so bad for it to be good especially since I was craving PP and read so much about this place.  Maybe their specialty is the banana creme pie, so IF I go back I'll try that.
Finally, if you take it to go put it in the fridge first because it is  really soft.
author: Molly M.

description:
The pie here is even more delicious than it looks, and that's hard to come by. They whip the cream by hand and give at-risk youth job training (it's like the pastry equivalent of Pedal Revolution - the two should have a kickball match ending in pie and bicycles). The pecan pie is really satisfying; the cinnamon pear pie tastes fresh from the tree. If you missed your farmers' market eggs, you can sometimes get eggs here too. You should also visit the Pie Ranch across from the ocean down on the 1 past Half Moon Bay where all the fillings come from. It's a magical place where they have volunteer work days (planting strawberries, hacking down raspberry bushes) and potluck barn dance hootenannies. The new, enlarged space isn't as cozy as the original, but it's probably better for them in many ways.

And if that weren't enough of a reason, how could you not love a place where employees think up signs like this:

"One day a customer took *eleven* napkins for one piece of pie! You would *never* do that."
author: Katrina D.

description:
Every time I go here, I feel like I'm at my Grandma's house in Atlanta, GA. The wallpaper brings back the memories of sitting around the kitchen table. 

Did you know they have their OWN farm, PIE RANCH? It is located in near Pescadero, on a pie shaped piece of land, hence the name. Also, the fact that there is an urban outreach program to youth gets me excited! Go go go! More kids to learn farming and where their food comes from HOOOODIEE HOOO!! 

I love the super healthy salad specials, the fact you can buy a dozen of their farm fresh eggs, and top it all off with a cup-o-joe and PIE. I suggest, Shaker Lemon, Pumpkin, or Pear-Ginger!! And of course, the Banana Creamiest. 

Mmm, who doesn't love pie?
author: Ingrid K.

description: I personally really like their banana cream pie but I think their fruit pies are mediocre. I had a peach pie today and there was no peach flavor whatsoever. The pie could not hold up and all the filling oozed out. And the bottom part of the crust was really soft. For $4 a slice, I would have expected something better and more heartier. Drip coffee was just okay too.  So not sure I would come back for any of their fruit pies. But I do like the ambiance. It's always a diverse group of people at this place in terms of age, race. You see families, a group of girlfriends, teenagers all hanging out and having food and drink. It's nice to have a place with a community feel which is atypical in the Mission. So three stars for ambiance and their banana cream pie! Taking away 2 stars for so-so fruit pies and small portions.
author: Nitya V.

description: If you dont like mission pie, there has to be something wrong with you. But the folks at MP are so nice, they may even be able to recommend where you can go for help, so go back and visit them :)
author: Vivek N.

description: Few things are more enjoyable than a late night pie. Great place to get communal and chat... I recommend the banana cream. Chocolate comes in second :)
author: Charles N.

description: my mission at mission pie was to get a slice of apple pie and wrangle it as quickly as possible. mission accomplished in about 47 seconds.
author: John B.

description:
Some say good pies are born, not made. I'm not sure how these pies were conceived, but they certainly are immaculate. 

If you're having a bad day, head straight to Mission Pie. You'll leave with a smile on your face. This establishment bakes its own on the premises and is up there among San Francisco's heavy hitters when it comes to dessert.

A good pie is in the pastry. Get that wrong and it doesn't matter what the filling is like, you'll feel like you're eating cardboard. Conversely, a good crust will carry a mediocre filling with aplomb.

At Mission Pie you get a great crust - flaky but not greasy, crisp, spry and generally delightful. The fillings are good - not brilliant, but I have no complaints at all. The walnut pie is a little on the dry side, but the flavour is good. The apricot fricase is sublime. Their berry pies have just a tinge of tartness to really activate the salival glands, I've not eaten a pie there that I wasn't enthusiastic about.

Definitely worthy of a mention are their scones (both sweet and savory), These have good body yet are just a little bit fluffy, which makes them perfect. Too often scones eat like house bricks, but not these ones.

At about $3-$4 for a pie/tartlet the prices are tolerable, but not quite as palatable as the pies.

Guys, if you want to make your woman really love you, take her to Mission Pie. She'll know then that you truly care for her.
author: Paul S.

description:
The Good: The pie was excellent. The crust crispy. The apples inside tart but sweet and firm. 

The Bad:
The slice of pie, I had to go, looked like someonelse's leftovers. It was maybe half of a normal piece of pie, crust broken and it looked like someone scraped the remnants of the pie tin into the box. It was like 3 bite pie.

The Ugly:
The guy who served me my pie had an open wound about the size of of a 50 cent piece on his wrist that glinted with that fresh infection look. He was also either sick or high. None of these things I like with my pie.

The annoying:
On the sign the said "Savory Pie" $4.00-$4.50" I ordered a pot pie, assuming it a savory pie because there was no other menu item to match it, and it was a $7.00 pie. Herumph. Also when I asked them to tell me the kinds of pie they had the pointed to the signs in front of the pie and said "they are labeled" the problem was all the signs were smeared beyond reading. Hellllo.
author: Kitten M.

description: On my  3rd visit, yesterday, I  had a slice of their Shaker Lemon pie and it was outstanding.  The crust was flaky and tasty, the lemon filling had bits of lemon peel - the taste and texture of the slice was really good.  I picked up a pear-raspberry pie and wow, especially reheated. it is delicious.  The service was fast and very friendly.  5 stars all around for Mission Pie.
author: Mark Z.

description: I had the Lemon pie.  I wasn't expecting it to be made out of actual lemons!  It was good, but tart from the rind.  The scone was very good too.
author: Anna S.

description: The pear raspberry pie is the best of all the pies i tasted there. The pie is so aromatic and subtle. The staff is pleasant and friendly.
author: Martin y.

description: A great place to get some writing done (especially since there is no pesky wi-fi to distract you with music blogs or mindy kaling's latest tweet). I love how bright it is on a sunny day - with the huge windows and perfect location in the Mission. Though, since there's no wi-fi, you might get distracted by the interesting-looking people who walk by constantly and occasionally cast leering looks in your direction (don't worry, it's just the pie) . Oh yeah, the pie. It's kind of perfect too.
author: Imran S.

description: the best pies ever! they're not heavy so you won't feel disgusting afterwards. instead, they're light, fluffy, and you can taste the quality. the banana cream pie is a must--it's a slice of heaven.
author: B K.

description:
Not only has Mission Pie introduced at least one other vegan pie to their lineup, they were very helpful and gracious about putting some aside for an all-vegan craft group that meets there. Great pie, great coffee, great staff: five stars!

Thanks, Mission Pie!
author: Jordan P.

description: its a bit high in price, but the meal was great it was a vegetarian lentils, with brown rice and swiss chad it was $8.50... I did not have pie for the main reason that its cooked on aluminum foil pans... but the service was great!!! i will returned as much as I love the Mission district to stay authentic I greatly enjoy that I have an option to Vegetarian non Mexican food.
author: Luna R.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. I was walking by and wanted to have a quick meal with my mom in between two events that we had on that neighborhood, we were starving and missed the dinner  on the first event due to our fabulous punctuality and walked into this place without knowing anything about it and to our surprise the decision we had to make to pick something from their menu was rather difficult.
I had a slice of their spinach and cheese pie and a cup of hot chocolate, the service was fast and my pie was freshly made and warm and the hot chocolate was spectacular. I like places like this with innovative ideas, non pretentious attitude, original menu items, fresh food, and good service.
I will be coming back for more!
author: Pamela L.

description: I had the mixed berry pie.  It was alright, but I would expect the same quality from safeway.  I don't think I will go out of my way to come back.  The building and inside were nice, but the pie... not so much
author: Jonathan U.

description:
OMG, I am so indebted to my friend G-Liscious C. for introducing me to Mission Pie.  And, while I'm very thankful, I'm also quite glad that it is far enough away that I cannot stop in very often, my diet just wouldn't be able to take it.

I went with my friend's suggestion of the Banana Cream, her favorite, and while it was delicious, I wish I'd gotten what she did that afternoon, the Ginger Pear.  I got a bite and it was a flavor explosion in your mouth, the light sweetness of the pear was perfect with the spiciness of the ginger, and this pie was full of both!  I love ginger, and now I think this is one of my favorite applications for it.  

In addition to the pie, I had a cup of Earl Grey tea, which is my favorite, and while it was a good tea, being served in a water glass, even with a sleeve, doesn't work.  For one thing, there is no saucer to put your tea bag on, so it's either leave it in the glass, put it on your pie plate (don't think so!  I don't want tea combining with my pie!) or on the table.  I left it in the glass and the last third of my tea was over-steeped.

Mission Pie is the kind of place I like to give business to.  Local businesses who don't stint on quality and bring in ingredients from local farms and producers, quite a bit of it organic, plus they give back to the community.  In addition to their delicious pies, what more can you ask for?
author: Crystal B.

description:
Whenever I've found myself in the vicinity of Mission Pie, I've craved more savoury things rather than sweet.  I can say that their Bacon and Radish Greens quiche is absolutely fabulous and delicious. Chicken Pot Pie is often on the menu.  

On another occasion I sampled their Plum Frangipane, and it was as though the heavens opened and a choir of angels belted out a chorus.  One of the best pies I'd had in a very looong time... If I had to do it over, I would have purchased an entire tart and consumed that.  

Though I am not always enamoured with everything on offer, the bright, cheery space is enough to put one in a happy mood the moment one steps foot in the door... Portions can be small, and while Twitter is a convenient way to keep up with their offerings it's not always updated.  

Nonetheless, I love the ethos and community spirit behind Mission Pie, and I'm eager to actually journey to a workday at Pie Ranch, and further support them that way.
author: Claudine C.

description: LIFE ALTERING PIES. Mission Pie, You have ruined me. I have never nor will I ever have a pie like your banana cream pie. It is heaven on earth. I wish you would open a location in Kansas City.
author: S G.

description:
Cherry Clafoutis is one of my guilty pleasures.  It's super satisfying at MPs.  Plus, any place open late(which means 10pm in San Francisco), I'm an immediate fan.

Pumpkin, strawberry rhubarb, walnut, pear with cranberries pies, shaker lemon...it's all good.  And don't forget a dollop of freshly whipped cream!  

***After writing this review, a craving hit and I had a 10 minutes to get to MPs before it closed.  I made it, but forgot the whipped cream:(
author: michelle s.

description:
Mission Pie just keeps getting better and better. The new space is much larger, yet still cozy and friendly.

I'm putting Mission Pie on my "Tea Time" list because they serve Taylor Maid Farms blends, which is just a darn good thing.
author: Jaina D.

description: Sweet potato pie a good standby after salsa class at Dance Mission.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Mission Pie has become a favorite spot for early morning work meetings because of its proximity to BART and the homes of a couple of my coworkers. We started meeting here in May and the place looked much different then because it was undergoing renovation. It was nice, but small. 

We came here again this past week and I was amazed by how great MP looks now. It's spacious but still retains most of the charm it had when it was smaller. This last time I finally had a pie and I realized why it's called Mission Pie: it actually had pretty decent pie. I had the spinach and cheese pie and was quite impressed. Their pie is MUCH better than their mochas, but then again, it's not called Mission Mocha. 

Perhaps I will one day start my own restaurant called Mission Gravy, which will feature a hearty menu of gravy fries, gravy burgers, gravy sandwiches and gravy martinis.
author: Lupe P.

description:
Very good. I love their Walnut Pie. Also had the Banana Cream which is made with thinly sliced bananas, and that wonderful crust. Lots of choices though... Hard to decide. Great coffee too.

Why 3 stars? My pie came room temp (which was fine), they didn't offer to heat it, and I know if I asked (even though I caught them in a lull) I felt like they would have balked. Also, once they got busy, they were so slow to serve, people in line started leaving. They are not managing their flow well, and for that reason, I probably wouldn't make a special trip down here on the chance I'd have to wait for 7 peoples lattes to be made before I could get a single slice and a cup o joe. But if I'm in the area and in the mood for pie, I would return and am sure I will.
author: Adam X.

description: 5 Freaking Stars for the most AMAZING Banana Cream Pie!!!!
author: Jessica C.

description: First of all, I don't like pies untill my boyfriend took me to this place. So far I only try cranberry apple pie, it really yummy with a whipping cream. Their coffee is also good , too. I like that everything there is organic and  from local farm , and the simplycity of this place . The tangerie fruits from local farm are the best one ( 50 cent/ each), I have to have at least one after finish a pie.  This place being one of my favorite places to go , enjoy n relax in a weekend.
author: christy l.

description:
Over the past year, I somehow became a very bitter and jaded person, finding something in everything to hate or complain about.

That being said, the ONLY problem I have with Mission Pies is that they're cash only.  Uhm, hello?  It's the 21st century and my unemployed ass never has cash.

Other than that, holy mackerel.  I could live and die on this food.  *SOOO* good.  Everything is.  Great location, great atmosphere, and AMAZING food.  So what are you waiting for??  Cash in your change bucket and get your butt over there!!!!!
author: Jess R.

description:
Besides Ba-racking the vote today, what could be more patriotic than having some good ol' American pie?!

Mission Pie serves up some heavenly pies -- call in to find out what the pies of the day are. The banana cream pie is so smooth and creamy with slices of banana in each bite. The crust is so crisp and golden, it's absolutely delectable. Get a whole pie for $18 or a slice for $3.50. The $2 mini walnut tarts are in season right now, and they make for a delicious little snack. 

Having one of their pies will really make you feel good about yourself too because it supports a great cause! Mission Pie serves as the urban link to Pie Ranch and to other local farms. Pie Ranch has developed a partnership with Mission High School to work with underserved students in order to introduce them to the life and business of a ranch. The shop provides the youth employment development part of the program by hiring 9 students. Pie Ranch is a place for "pie in the sky" idealistic thinking to guide social change (http://www.pieranch.org/why.html). Guilt-free pie is the best kind of pie there is!

Now, be a proud American and goBAMA out and vote, and then treat yourself to some delicious pie!
author: Connie C.

description:
Three words: banana. cream. pie.

It really is that delicious. The crust: so flaky, crisp, and buttery, not dry and crumbly. The bananas, fresh and still firm, not brown and mushy. The cream, sweet like sweet cream, not too sugary-sweet. 

I could eat the entire pie by myself in one sitting if left to my own devices.

They also have savory pies here -- something I need to remember. If they use the same crust on all the pies, I'm in trouble.
author: Sabine S.

description:
Pie Pie Pie! Pie Pie Pie!
*slamming silverware on the table*

I am stoked on pie after having a slice of Mission Pie's incredible banana creme variety last weekend. I've heard great things for a long time now, but that was my first time. I don't want to rush to judgment & throw five stars at the joint, but at the same time PPPPPIIIIIIIEEEEEE!!!!!!111

They didn't have strawberry rhubarb available when I was there (not in season just yet). If they can somehow create one as tasty as my mom's, I will have to punt a kitten just to make up for it. The universe will need to come into balance somehow, & anything short of violence towards the innocent just won't do.

So, note to Mission Pie: If you don't want me to explode with violent pie-induced glee, you'd better keep ya pies hid when you hear me walking down the street.
author: Pete J.

description:
I guess there was a reason why I never went south of 24th St, with the exception of La Taqueria.

I went there around 7pm on a weekday and picked up a slice of banana cream pie and a personal size huckleberry pie/tart. The bcp crust was not flaky or buttery and had a consistency of a crisp cracker. Wish there were more banana slices. If you let Elmer's glue dry for 30 minutes, you would then have the consistency of the cream filling. Totally unappealing. 
The huckleberry tart was better than the bcp and had a nice crumbly topping. The fruit had a nice texture and was sweet but not overpowering. 

Would I try this place again? Sure, I will give them a second chance.
author: Evan W.

description:
There are few things in life that I love more than pie. Sunrises, the smile on a child's face, Haagen-Dazs, spandex, midget creamed corn wrestling. You get the picture. Pie is definitely up there.

I stumbled upon this tiny pie cafe after waddling out of La Taqueria, my belly taut and wobbling full of carnitas. "Ugh. SO...FULL. Pie? Mmmm." I had to check it out. 

This type of behavior is not part of my "New Me in 2007" plan. In fact, it's quite reminiscent of the "Old Me in 2006." And "2005." And "2004." Well, you get it.

The place is tiny but quaint and the selection of pies was limited to just apple and banana cream but they've only been open since the beginning of the month. They use an all butter crust with organic flour and fruit. I appreciate that. The pie is very good. I prefer a slightly crispier crust but the butter is of good quality and the fruit was perfectly cooked and not too sweet. I spent a year making pies every week trying to perfect this art so trust me, I know good pie from bad.

There's also a selection of muffins, scones and tarts as well as coffee and tea. I REALLY love the idea of a pie cafe so please come here and support this local pie baker.

The first rays of sunlight on a crisp early morn
midgets in combat waist-deep in creamed corn 
Warm apple pie with real whipped cream toppings
These are a few of my favorite things...
author: Josua P.

description:
Doesn't this seem like the kind of joint that would have something vegan? I mean, I'm as omnivore as the next asshole, but I'm no philistine and I know that if you're selling baked goods in the 94110 and you're preaching the message of do-goodery all over town, then it shouldn't be a huge surprise if a percentage of your potential customers don't rock dairy and eggs, no? And what of the allergic crowd? But anyway, we can't be all things to all people and I get that. It was just a bit of a weird reception to a perfectly matter of fact, polite inquiry if in fact anything was free of the animal byproducts. It was a funny response, too: "Well, we sometimes have these muffins, but they sell out really fast."

Hmmm. Sounds like Econ 101 to me. Supply, demand, guns, butter, etc. 

Anyway, the banana cream pie was indeed slammin' (I said I wasn't vegan, okay?) but I hate whipped cream and I don't understand why it has to be all over every damn thing. But the inside part, with the bananas and the custard was definitely the kind of thing I would pay $3.50 for. The sweet potato pie, maybe not so much. I don't know. It was fine. The coffee was good. The people behind the counter are adorable, and then there's the aforementioned do-goodery. So that's good.
author: Megan W.

description:
My favorite guy is the guy with the mustache. He reminds me of Rick Moranis in Ghost Busters. When I asked him if they normally heat up the pie slices, he said something like, "well, no, historically speaking, in the middle ages, they would've normally kept the pie at room temperature." I liked that.

I also like the pie at this place. Good crust, not too sweet, and they serve it with home-made whipped cream, which is a nice touch. 

Another thing that's good at Mission Pie is there's a button on the door that if you push it, the door will open AUTOMATICALLY. I know, right?
author: Nathaniel L.

description: They even have vegan pies! I order a different pie every time I go in and I havn't gone wrong. If you're not in a rush, I would definitely eat in (versus take out) and ask for the pie to be heated with one scoop of their homemade vanilla ice cream. Yum!
author: Zaina O.

description: Love this place. It's very very chill. I'm not too huge on the eco-friendly efforts, just because I don't practice it, but I love that they do. The pies, tarts, salads and coffee are to DIE for! I would think just about everything they offer is delicious. So why 4 stars instead of 5? Well it gets a wee bit pricey there, not to say if you consider things are organic, natural, fair trade, local and sustainable, it isn't worth it, but to some 3.50 a slice is a little steep. The price limits my visits, but you can bet your sweet apple pie that I'll be back at least 3 times in a year. One more thing, parents, while the atmo is totally chill and there is a little kiddie play table, I don't really feel like this is a kid friendly place. And not by the staff, whom are very friendly and awesome, but the customers. They don't exactly seem to appreciate children in the joint.
author: Desiree B.

description:
With La Taqueria, Dianda's, and the Mission Cultural Center, 25th & Mission is a useful corner, and now you can watch it all from the tall windows of the newly expanded Mission Pie.  (Ok, so it's not 4th & King, but giving people a view of the intersection just might raise its profile).  

Now of course it's easy to rave about a pie store, but I've always liked the idea of pie more than I like pie itself (especially when it comes to fruit pies), so I'm not the best judge of tastiness.  But I do know a good, flaky crust when I taste one, and Mission Pie has got that aspect down.  And I must admit, bringing their white-and-red-peach pie to a picnic and then heating it on the charcoal grill (with the foil bottom still on, of course), worked wonderfully, and the fruit slices and glazy syrup certainly have the all-natural taste that's become de rigueur in California.  For the true test, I'll have to come back in winter for one of the nuttier/creamier/pumpkinier pies that are more to my heart's delight.
author: Wes M.

description: Warm and welcoming pie shop with wildflowers on all the tables....can anything be better?
author: Leora M.

description:
I've been walking by this place five days a weeks for the past 3 years. I never gave it much notice until they put those lovely windows up on Mission street. When there was no windows I had not a clue what this place was about. Now you can see the patrons with their coffee/pie/scone/etc looking oh so happy. There is usually a good amount of people in here most days of the week which is a good indicator of how good this place is.                                                                  
        I came in after hearing of some amazing scones. Already having a "scone place", I had to do my own comparison. My first impression was that my scone was not warm. Wtf! However, a mouthful later I realized that it didn't really matter. The buttery goodness more than made up for it. It is dangerous having such numminess so accessible to me (almost) everyday, but luckily the line is usually too long in the morning and I am usually rushing to work.

 I highly recommend stopping by for some coffee, and a scone of course.
author: Mary Ann G.

description:
This review is a work in progress.  It's incomplete.  Because really, how can you judge a place by one single slice of pie?  One, freshly glorious, creamy, crunchy-crusted slice of banana cream pie that just about knocked my socks off, and banana cream isn't even my favorite? (I had gone in hoping for something with rhubarb, but no luck).  

No, more research is definitely needed.  I'm gonna have to go back...
author: DD B.

description:
Saturday afternoon.  I'm standing in line at Mission Pie, waiting to pick up my reserved Banana Cream Pie, which I am buying for a dinner party we are having later that night.  Pie with a cause, wow, that's so cool....(drifting off into thought....)

Pie Ranch.  Birthplace of Mission Pie. Land spreading out under blue skies.  I envision is myself astride a strong horse, with a lasso in hand,  and my eye on a renegade sweet potato pie....swinging the rope....aiming....gotcha!  Yeee haw!!!

*poof* fantasy over.

Mission Pie is a homey little place on 25th Street, off of Mission.  A handpainted wooden sign advertising pie on Mission Street ensures that you don't wander too far away from your destination.

The Banana Cream Pie was delicious.  Nice thick custard filling, plenty of bananas, not too sweet, with a rich cream topping.  Good crust.  Not too heavy with an all-natural flavor.

I also got a slice of Apple Pie to try.  Simple and very good - tender but not soggy apples, good crust, no gelatinous filling.  

I will definitely be back, perhaps to enjoy a cup of coffee and a slice at one of the tables, or to get a pie when I am hosting or when I am a guest.  

Pie.  Mmmmmm.
author: Liz S.

description: The savoury pies are good, and not too expensive, and a good selection of sweet pies.  You can take them away aswell, which I regularly do on my way home if I want something cheap and easy for dinner!
author: Rob G.

description:
Me (with a megaphone): Alright!!! Who here likes pie?!?!?!?

[[SF/X: roar of approval]]

MWM: Stupid question...okay, now who here likes practically home-made Good Citizen, community member, part-of-the-solution, Literacy pie, over crappy old everyday store-bought pie?!?!?!?

[[SF/X: polite applause, dies down quickly]]

MWM: Did I mention that the pie filling is made with produce from Half Moon Bay or nearby Pacifica---I forget---anyhow does that do anything for you?!?!?!?

[[SF/X: crickets]]

MWM: Tough crowd. Right. Who here likes pie with coffee?!?!?!?

[[SF/X: slightly restrained, not-quite roar of approval]]

MWM: Fine. Come with me then, philistines. If you want pie.

[[SF/X: hems, haws, much discussion]]

MWM: God you're all troublesome. This is the last time I offer to babysit a room full of sound effects. Seriously. I'm going to go get pie!

[[SF/X: more discussion]]

MWM: BALLS to you! Slams door in huff!
author: Jeremy W.

description:
I know my pie. It's quite simple really...crusty on the outside and sweet and gooey on the inside. Well, sometimes the inside can be savory and salty too. But at Mission Pie, it's all about dessert pies. Normally, I like my senses to be blown away when I have dessert, but I guess with old age comes an appreciation of the subtle flavors. 

The peach olallieberry did it for me. It was really the first time I've tasted pie that was naturally sweetened by the fruit and not some brown sugary mixture... it was just like biting into a perfectly ripened white peach on a summer day. I love a good crust too, but the bottom crust was soggy and top crust was a little dry and bland. I also tried the walnut pie, which was similar to a pecan pie...too sweet even for my tastes with its sugary, corn syrupy filling. 

Mission Pie's website lists its pies of the day, but it doesn't seem to be consistently updated (also check out the story of how they began). I can't wait to go back and try more pie. Next time, I'll have to stick my finger into some cream pie...
author: Mimi L.

description: I had high hopes, seeing that other yelp reviewers gave it positive ratings, but I was disappointed.  I ordered the chicken pot pie and found it lacking in taste, although the crust was yummy.  My friend shared the pie as well  and decided to add some Tobasco for flavoring, because it was pretty bland.  The fennel pie or whatever they named it was pretty good.  Then we tried a piece of peach pie and we both felt the peaches were not fresh, but instead canned.  If correct, they earned the low score I gave them.  Lastly, we tried the apricot tart and again I thought the apricots were canned, but she disagreed.  Whatever the case, canned or fresh, Mission Pie gets only 2 stars from me.  I won't be patronizing them again anytime soon, not when there are a host of other better pies out there
author: Anson D.

description:
There are so many things I love about this place, it's hard to decide where to start.

First of all, I love the decor. It's a home-feeling country dining room oasis in an urban neighborhood. The sunny yellow walls and the rich wooden furniture give it the feel of a cozy bed and breakfast.

And of course, the pies. They said their best-sellers are the banana cream pies, so I decided to try some. Let me be honest...$3.80 is a small price to pay for a little slice of heaven. The crust was light and flaky. The bananas were ripe and the cream was was whipped to perfection.

The other thing I really loved about this place was the atmosphere. It was very welcoming and very relaxing. It's the perfect place to take an intimate group of friends for dessert. One of the best things for me was seeing a bunch of adults eating pie and drinking glasses of milk. Milk!! When was the last time you saw an adult drinking a glass of milk in public?! It was great!

My only regret is that I was too full from dinner to have another slice of pie. Definitely check this place out if you get the chance!
author: Teresa G.

description:
A socially just, ethically sound reason to get fat! Can I getta HELLYES!?!?!? One bite is all it takes to be swept off your feet by these delicious, organic, all-natural pies. These are now my go-to pies for late lonely nights spent chowing down in the dark and wishing that all these extra pounds could be cried away...I digress.

This is one excellent operation, focused on health, education, and sustainable outcomes for youth and the community at large. Truly a way to indulge with little to no guilt. I highly recommend the Walnut pie (crunchy and crisp and not too sweet), the Sweet Potato Pie (like custard), and the Ginger Pear (spicy and sweet and perfect). The crust is by far the best part, and I am usually no fan of crust. The Meyer Lemon Pie (may be out of season now) is to die for as are most of their seasonal treats I've had the pleasure of trying. 

Because I am the luckiest bastard on the face of the earth, there are Mission Pies laying around my office kitchen all the time, making them incredibly accessible to me. But if they weren't practically shoving themselves down my throat on any given day, the trip over the the Mission would be more than worth it.
author: Autumn K.

description: I was so excited about this place, but wow it was so not what I expected.  I read all the reviews and figured it would be a damn good pie.  Well, when I went in yesterday I asked for a slice of peach and banana cream to go. When I got home and opened my packages, I discovered the SMALLEST slice of pie ever.  Honestly, i've been to bakeries that give out SAMPLES that are bigger.  But, whatever, I thought once I try it it'll probably be amazing.  NOPE.  The banana cream is topped with either cool whip or cream from a can, the crust was burnt.  YUCK!  I opened the peach pie container to discover a very burnt piece of pie and when i bit into it I realized that they used CANNED peaches!  Yes people, CANNED!  This place is gross...
author: Lolo H.

description: This place was over rated.  Typical Hipsterville.  The pies fell short.
author: Pink G.

description:
I'd been talking about trying this place for a long time.  So last week, my buddy and I were sitting at a traffic light and I was rattling on about how I wanted a snack, but what should I get, I don't want to try to find parking in the Inner Mission, why can't I figure out what I want to eat, and on and on like this when suddenly she goes, "PIE!  Eat pie!"  And she points at this unadorned, barely detectable sign that said "Mission Pie" hanging above a tiny door that leads into a store with tinted windows.  It was all very mysterious.

I was excited for Mission Pie, but also skeptical.  Cause, you know, they're kind of selling charity pies.  And charity pies are usually bad because you're buying them to support a cause and not because they're particularly good.  And organizations usually know they're selling you their politics and the wholesome, happy feeling of giving back, so they don't bother making a truly tasty product.

But not so with Mission Pie.  They make the world a happier place with their thick, flakey crusts and fresh, flavorful fillings and commitment to urban education and protecting natural resources.  Very nice.

I threw down $5 for a "Mini" Banana Cream Pie and $2 for a walnut tartlet that was roughly the size of a Reese's peanut butter cup.  I got the tiny versions because, as aforementioned, I was worried they would be bad and then I would be stuck with a bunch of bad pie.  I ended up stomping around my house licking the empty pie box wishing I had ordered more food.  Spending $7 for about 12 bites of food didn't seem so outrageous to me after I'd tasted the pies.
author: Diana Y.

description: They only take cash and checks, presumably to be ironic.  I tried a savory pie, and it was okay but not worth the $22.
author: Paul K.

description:
The last time I really liked pie was when McDonald's used to deep fry their "apple pie." I am just not that big of a fan of the UFO like baked good... well that all changed on a Sunday Birthday outing (Thank you Lisa for choosing Mission Pie as a gathering spot).

1. The space is super charming. Vaulted ceiling, interesting pendants, overall airy and relaxing space.
2. Staff is kind and informative.
3. Lemonade! Jesus Mary Joseph and Mary's Two other kids that are never mentioned... that stuff is tartly delicious!
4. The pies are mega-lo delicious-o. I asked the dude behind the counter what he like between banana cream and walnut. he steered me towards the walnut and it was amazing. Just the right amount of sweet balanced the the right amount of salt with a great texture on the crust... with the best dollop of whipped cream I have ever had... and I don't like whipped cream!
5. The crazy hipsters doing interpretative dance outside the front window.

Pie is good again folks.
author: danny e.

description:
It's great that Mission Pie supports the youth and is run by the youth. It's got the whole organic ingredient thing going on as well. It's a cute shop nestled in the Mission District and is now covered by construction on the building at the corner so you'll have to walk past that in order to spot it. 

I had read the reviews so I knew exactly what to order. Two slices of the apple pie and two slices of the banana creme pie. I have to say its one of the best banana creme pies that i've ever had. None of that whip cream filling up 3/4 of the pie complaint here. You get the real deal. It's filled with slices of banana and is just delicious. The crust is perfect as well. The apple pie was pretty good, but I can't say it's the best i've had. They do give a generous amount of sliced apples as filling. Normally pies tend to be too sweet, but not here. We also ordered two small coffees, which you get a free refill for if eating in. Good coffee/nice aroma.

Overall, it's a nice dessert place if you're craving something sweet after a meal. $3.50 a slice and $1.50 for a small coffee.
author: Veronica H.

description:
Compromise sucks when I don't make the call. But sometimes it turns out to taste pretty damn good in the end.

After the show at the Marsh, I wanted to go to Ritual. Adam wanted to go to Mission Pie. I quasi-sulked on the way there.

Then we walked in. Cute! And closing in 10 minutes, so take your choice (and a compostable fork) and we'll see you later.

I like very much. But compromise, well, I'm still working on that.
author: Allison L.

description:
Ever before I had been used to thinking of banana cream pies as being these somewhat over sugary confection consumed for a mega-dose of cream.  No more.  The banana cream pie at Mission Pie is a completely different concoction.  Never before have I tasted a banana cream pie that was so....well, so bananay.  I could taste the banana that was used to make the pie at Mission Pie.  

It's too sad that I went there after a very full meal at Mi Lindo Peru with Arnold and Christel (read the gluttonous review below).  Otherwise, I could have gone for a second slice to try out something more.  There were so many beautiful pies on display.  The strawberry looked so tempting.  The ones I really want to try out is the Mystie meat pies; how cool is that. Happily for me, Mission Pie is quite close by.

I would dock half a star only because Mission Pie the crust isn't as flaky as desirable.  However, maybe I would also raise them back a half a star because they invested in farm equipment for the organic farm with whom they work.  

Mission Pie: look for the neon pie sign.  So good that we were willing to eat standing in the tiny little place.
_______

The tiny little walnut tarts are incredible.  Make sure to get one...even if you had a slice of pie (it's pretty small, you can eat it, I am sure you can).

Oh, and the apple galette was very nice as well.  Not too sweet.  Perfect heated up...if only I had thought to get some really good vanilla ice cream with it....
author: Sooj O.

description:
Mission Pie has great pie, a comfortable atmosphere and an admirable mission statement.
I've come here to meet friends or just enjoy some dessert multiple times. I like to sit at the community table and people watch inside and out.
Once I was here when a school group was singing and playing instruments, just great!
author: Rachel M.

description:
Finally had a chance to sit down and have some of their famous Banana Cream Pie.  It was probably the best I have ever had (not too much whipped cream on the top vs. filling)  Perhaps a couple of more slices of banana would have been nice, but I am not complaining,  Also took home a whole walnut pie last Thanksgiving, which was also spot on.

Do note that they only take cash or checks (at least on the sign on the cash register), in case you want to take home a whole pie, or normally don't carry much cash around.
author: Peter L.

description:
The pie is sublime, especially the walnut. The seasonal pear with ginger is insanely good. 
Fresh peach is fabulous, as well - they leave the skins on the peaches for a touch of tartness. 
The young barristas are sweet, and the clientele is refreshingly diverse. What a great addition to the neighborhood. (I only hope it doesn't turn into too much of a scene.) We love Mission Pie!
author: Julie B.

description:
My dudes.  You don't even know.

The first thing you'll notice is the fat EAT PIE neon sign in the window of a large key-lime-green Victorian building on the corner of 25th and Mission.  

The second thing you'll notice is the big blackboard next to the unmarked front door listing the pie flavors available.  You'll make special note of the fact that strawberry-rhubarb, ollallaberry, walnut, banana cream, pear, peach, sweet potato, and apple are among your favorite words on earth and that their stock is now quickly rising.

The third thing you'll notice is the astonishingly large display of pies.  At this point, your right brain will shoot your left brain in the face and take over -- and you will surrender.

On my first visit, I chose a slice of their strawberry-rhubarb.  Yum-to-the-mee!  Tree-fiddy buys some seriously happy taste buds and some pie cred.  

On my second visit, I togo'd 3 pies -- peach, strawberry-rhubarb, and walnut -- for my homies at work.  The pies were scarfed down in less than 12 minutes.  

On my third visit, I bought a banana cream pie to share with my friends, and I was rewarded with soft mmmmms of pleasure as they inhaled their generous slices. 

On my last visit, I became the proud owner of the last ollallaberry pie of the day - oh my sh*t, that thing was epic.  Flaky mouth-melty buttery crust, not-too-sweet fruit filling, a hint of grandma and sunshine and fluffy pillows.

All this oral gratification, a friendly staff and compostable forks too.  Their awesomeness has no bounds, apparently.

Now you know.
author: Caroline E.

description:
Good pie. I'm no pie connoisseur, but it was pretty darn good. I got the banana cream pie which I was told is among the most popular.  The filling was deliciously creamy and smooth, almost like a banana pudding or custard, and the crust was deliciously buttery but not too overpowering. Mmm, I'm craving more now.  
I really like the cozy atmosphere too. Cute wallpaper, nice seating arrangement, adorable sign in the window that says "Eat Pie!"
But I would argue that the best part about Mission Pie is neither the atmosphere nor the pie, but the cool story behind it.  Using nearby Pie Ranch (about an hour from the city) to teach local students from Mission High about agriculture and then helping them get business experience by working at Mission Pie = very cool idea.
Yay Mission Pie!!!
author: Laura P.

description:
Just checked this place out for the first time since it re-opened in its larger space. It's been a while. I've enjoyed Mission Pie ever since it was in its tiny space, but now with the bigger space, it seems like the slices have gotten even smaller (as if they weren't small enough already). My favorite banana cream pie isn't as flavorful as I remember it being and  the crust was too dry/hard for my fork to break so I ended up using my fingers to do the job. Even the staff behind the counter look more disgruntled now than ever before.

Don't think I'll be returning anytime soon.
author: Zell C.

description:
Just awful service.

When you go to a pie shop, you imagine being greeted by an old grandma who just can't wait to share with you her delightful pies. That is definitely not the experience you get here. My bf went to get a whole pie, and understandably they did not have any left since it was close to closing time.
